title: Ezekiel Chapter 38 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 38 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 38 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who is Ezekiel commanded to prophesy against in Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: Gog
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:2 commands the son of man to set his face against Gog and prophesy against him.

questions.question: What is Gog described as in Ezekiel 38:2?
options: The chief prince of Meshech and Tubal
questions.correctAnswer: The chief prince of Meshech and Tubal
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:2 identifies Gog as the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 38:5, which nations are mentioned as allies with Gog?
questions.correctAnswer: Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:5 lists Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya as allies with Gog.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 38:9: 'Thou shalt ascend and come like a _______, thou shalt be like a cloud to cover the land.'
questions.correctAnswer: storm
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:9 says, 'Thou shalt ascend and come like a storm'.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 38:10 says Gog will think an evil thought at the same time as the Lord's prophecy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:10 says Gog shall think an evil thought at the same time.

questions.question: What will Gog say he will do to the land of unwalled villages according to Ezekiel 38:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Take a spoil and prey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:11 states Gog says he will go to take a spoil and prey from the unwalled villages.

questions.question: Who questions Gog about taking spoil and prey in Ezekiel 38:13?
options: Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish
questions.correctAnswer: Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:13 mentions Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish questioning Gog.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 38:14 says Gog will not know when Israel dwells safely.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:14 says Gog will not know it when Israel dwells safely.

questions.question: From which direction will Gog come according to Ezekiel 38:15?
questions.correctAnswer: The north parts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:15 states Gog will come from the north parts.

questions.question: What will happen to the mountains and walls when Gog comes, as described in Ezekiel 38:20?
options: Mountains will be thrown down and walls will fall
Mountains will grow taller and walls will strengthen
Mountains will shake but walls remain standing
Mountains and walls will remain unchanged
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains will be thrown down and walls will fall
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:20 describes mountains being thrown down and walls falling to the ground.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 38:21 says every man's sword will be against his brother during this conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:21 says every man's sword shall be against his brother.

questions.question: What will God use against Gog and his bands according to Ezekiel 38:22?
options: Pestilence, blood, hailstones, fire, and brimstone
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence, blood, hailstones, fire, and brimstone
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:22 lists pestilence, blood, hailstones, fire, and brimstone as God's weapons.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 38:23, what will God magnify and sanctify?
questions.correctAnswer: Himself
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:23 says God will magnify and sanctify Himself.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of bringing Gog against the land of Israel as stated in Ezekiel 38:16?
options: So the heathen may know God and He is sanctified in Gog
questions.correctAnswer: So the heathen may know God and He is sanctified in Gog
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:16 says God will bring Gog against Israel so the heathen may know Him and He is sanctified in Gog.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 38:4: 'And I will turn thee back, and put ______ into thy jaws.'
questions.correctAnswer: hooks
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:4 says God will put hooks into Gog's jaws.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 38 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 38 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is worried about facing overwhelming opposition in their spiritual walk. Based on Ezekiel 38, what truth can you share about God's sovereignty in such trials?
options: God will use the opposition to display His power and sanctify Himself.
Believers must rely solely on their own strength to overcome.
Opposition means God has abandoned His people.
The enemy's plans will always succeed without God's intervention.
questions.correctAnswer: God will use the opposition to display His power and sanctify Himself.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:16 and 38:23 show that God brings Gog against Israel so that He may be sanctified and known among many nations. This teaches that God is sovereign over opposition and uses it to reveal His glory.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 38 teach us about trusting God’s protection during times of danger and uncertainty?
options: God promises to defend His people and cause confusion among their enemies.
We must isolate ourselves and avoid all risks to be safe.
Trusting in human strength is the best protection.
Ignoring threats will make them disappear.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to defend His people and cause confusion among their enemies.
questions.explanation: Verses 21–22 describe God calling for a sword against Gog and causing strife among his forces, showing that God actively defends His people, encouraging believers to trust Him in danger.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their efforts to serve others seem unnoticed. What does Ezekiel 38 teach about God's ultimate purpose in allowing trials and opposition?
options: God uses trials to magnify and sanctify Himself, making His name known.
Trials are meaningless and only cause suffering.
Opposition means God is displeased with our service.
Serving others is futile if not publicly recognized.
questions.correctAnswer: God uses trials to magnify and sanctify Himself, making His name known.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:23 emphasizes that God magnifies and sanctifies Himself through these events so that many nations will know Him, teaching that trials have a divine purpose beyond our understanding.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 38 encourage believers to approach prayer when facing threats or spiritual battles?
options: Pray with confidence that God is sovereign and will act on behalf of His people.
Prayer is unnecessary because God has predetermined everything.
Only pray when you feel strong and capable.
Avoid praying about conflicts to prevent worry.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray with confidence that God is sovereign and will act on behalf of His people.
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s active intervention against Gog (verses 18-22), teaching believers to trust in God’s power and pray confidently amid spiritual battles.

questions.question: What lesson about humility can a believer learn from God’s declaration against Gog in Ezekiel 38?
options: Human pride and evil plans ultimately fail before God’s sovereignty.
Pride is necessary to succeed in spiritual battles.
God favors the proud and powerful.
Planning evil is wise and effective.
questions.correctAnswer: Human pride and evil plans ultimately fail before God’s sovereignty.
questions.explanation: Verse 10-11 describe Gog’s evil thoughts, but God declares opposition and judgment against him, highlighting that prideful schemes cannot triumph over God’s will.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear about the future. According to Ezekiel 38, what encouragement can you share about God’s promises for His people?
options: God promises safety and restoration for His people despite future attacks.
Fear should lead us to abandon faith.
The future is hopeless without human effort.
God’s promises depend on our perfect obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises safety and restoration for His people despite future attacks.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 speaks of Israel dwelling safely after being gathered from many nations, showing God’s promise of restoration and security even amid trials.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God’s justice and wrath can be drawn from Ezekiel 38 when facing injustice or oppression?
options: God will execute justice against the wicked with fury and righteous anger.
God ignores injustice and allows it to continue unchecked.
Justice is only human responsibility, not God’s.
questions.correctAnswer: God will execute justice against the wicked with fury and righteous anger.
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 describe God’s fury and jealousy rising against Gog, demonstrating that God actively judges injustice and protects His people.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 38 guide believers to maintain integrity and faithfulness in their daily work amid challenges?
options: Trust God’s sovereign plan and work diligently without fear of opposition.
Avoid challenging tasks to prevent failure.
Success depends only on human ability.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s sovereign plan and work diligently without fear of opposition.
questions.explanation: The chapter reveals God’s control over events (verses 4-6) encouraging believers to trust Him and remain faithful and diligent regardless of difficulties encountered.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 38, God’s people will always be protected by physical walls and gates.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states that the people dwell in unwalled villages, indicating their safety is due to God’s protection, not physical barriers.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 38 teaches that God’s glory will be revealed through the judgment of His enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 23 clearly states that God will magnify and sanctify Himself so that many nations will know Him through these judgments.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 38 teaches us that God will bring Gog and his armies from the __________ parts to attack Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: north
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states that Gog will come from the north parts, teaching believers about God’s control over the direction of events.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 38 guide believers on practicing forgiveness and love in the face of hostility or attack?
options: Trust God to bring justice while responding with patience and love.
Hold grudges to protect personal interests.
Avoid reconciliation as it shows weakness.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to bring justice while responding with patience and love.
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s sovereign judgment against enemies (verses 21-22), encouraging believers to leave vengeance to God and maintain love and patience.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 38, what can believers learn about humility in their relationship with God and others?
options: Recognize God’s ultimate authority and submit to His will.
Assert personal dominance to gain respect.
Ignore God’s plans and rely on self.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s ultimate authority and submit to His will.
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 17 remind us that God is against Gog and has spoken through prophets, teaching believers to humbly submit to God's sovereign will.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 38 teach about the importance of spiritual vigilance and preparation for believers?
options: Be prepared and watchful because spiritual battles will come.
Ignore warnings since God will always protect without effort.
questions.correctAnswer: Be prepared and watchful because spiritual battles will come.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 commands Gog to be prepared, implying believers also need readiness and vigilance in their spiritual walk.

questions.question: What biblical virtue related to stewardship and generosity does Ezekiel 38 imply when mentioning the gathering of people with cattle and goods?
options: God blesses His people with possessions to be used responsibly and shared.
Possessions are a sign of personal superiority.
Hoarding wealth protects you from enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses His people with possessions to be used responsibly and shared.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 describes the people with cattle and goods gathered in the land, indicating God’s provision, which calls for faithful stewardship and generosity.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 38 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who is identified as the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, against whom Ezekiel is commanded to prophesy?
questions.correctAnswer: Gog
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:2 explicitly names Gog as the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal to whom the prophecy is directed.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will put into Gog's jaws to bring him forth?
questions.correctAnswer: Hooks
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:4 states that the LORD will put hooks into Gog's jaws to turn him back and bring him forth along with his army.

questions.question: Which of the following nations is NOT listed among Gog's allies in Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:5-6 lists Persia, Ethiopia, Libya, Gomer, and Togarmah but does not mention Babylon as an ally.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'in the latter days' in Ezekiel 38:8 and 38:16 within the prophetic context?
options: It refers to a future eschatological period of Israel’s restoration
It indicates a historical event during Ezekiel's lifetime
It describes a past Babylonian invasion
It symbolizes the creation of the world
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to a future eschatological period of Israel’s restoration
questions.explanation: The phrase 'in the latter days' in Ezekiel 38:8 and 38:16 points to a prophetic time when Israel is restored and at peace, often associated with end-time events.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 38:11, how does Gog describe the land of Israel?
options: A land of unwalled villages, dwelling safely without bars or gates
A fortified city with strong walls and gates
A desolate wilderness with no inhabitants
A mountainous region with many fortresses
questions.correctAnswer: A land of unwalled villages, dwelling safely without bars or gates
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:11 records Gog's thought of attacking a land where people dwell safely without walls, bars, or gates, indicating vulnerability.

questions.question: Which groups question Gog’s motives for gathering his company to take spoil according to Ezekiel 38:13?
options: Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish
questions.correctAnswer: Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:13 names Sheba, Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish as those who question Gog’s intent to take spoil and prey.

questions.question: What divine purpose is revealed in Ezekiel 38:16 for bringing Gog against the land of Israel?
options: So that the heathen may know God and He is sanctified in Gog
To destroy the city of Jerusalem completely
To punish Israel for their sins
To establish Gog’s kingdom over Israel
questions.correctAnswer: So that the heathen may know God and He is sanctified in Gog
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:16 states that God brings Gog against Israel so that the nations will recognize God’s holiness and power, manifested through this event.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 38 portrays Gog as acting without any knowledge or warning from previous prophets.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:17 indicates that Gog is the very one spoken of by the ancient prophets, so his coming is foretold and known.

questions.question: What natural and supernatural phenomena accompany God’s fury against Gog according to Ezekiel 38:19-20?
options: A great shaking of the land, mountains thrown down, animals and people trembling
A flood covering the entire earth
A complete darkness lasting for three days
questions.correctAnswer: A great shaking of the land, mountains thrown down, animals and people trembling
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:19-20 describes a cataclysmic shaking causing mountains and steep places to fall and all creatures trembling at God's presence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 38:22, God says He will plead against Gog with _______, blood, overflowing rain, great hailstones, fire, and brimstone.
questions.correctAnswer: pestilence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:22 explicitly mentions pestilence among the means God uses to bring judgment upon Gog and his armies.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 38:20 to emphasize the cosmic scale of the judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole
questions.explanation: The description of all creatures shaking and mountains falling in Ezekiel 38:20 uses hyperbolic language to convey the overwhelming power of God’s judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the north as the origin of Gog’s invasion in Ezekiel 38:15?
options: The north historically represented enemies of Israel and divine judgment
It symbolizes the place of God’s throne
It refers to the direction of the sun’s rising
It is the homeland of the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The north historically represented enemies of Israel and divine judgment
questions.explanation: Biblical prophecy often associates the north with hostile powers coming against Israel, as seen in Ezekiel 38:15 and other prophetic texts.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 38:23 describe God's ultimate purpose in the judgment against Gog?
options: To magnify and sanctify Himself so many nations will know He is the LORD
To establish Gog’s kingdom over Israel
To punish Israel for their rebellion
To bring about the end of the world
questions.correctAnswer: To magnify and sanctify Himself so many nations will know He is the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:23 clearly states that God uses this event to reveal His holiness and sovereignty to many nations.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents the typology of Gog and Magog in biblical eschatology as reflected in Ezekiel 38?
options: Enemies of God’s people representing final opposition before divine victory
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies of God’s people representing final opposition before divine victory
questions.explanation: Gog and Magog typify eschatological adversaries in biblical literature, foreshadowing final conflict before God's ultimate triumph.

questions.question: What does the imagery of 'a cloud to cover the land' in Ezekiel 38:9 and 38:16 symbolize regarding Gog’s invasion?
options: An overwhelming, dark, and unstoppable force
A gentle rain nurturing the land
questions.correctAnswer: An overwhelming, dark, and unstoppable force
questions.explanation: The simile of a cloud covering the land conveys the vastness and threatening nature of Gog’s invasion as an overwhelming force.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 38 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 38 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is identified as the chief prince against whom Ezekiel is commanded to prophesy in Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: Gog
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:2-3 clearly identifies Gog as the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal against whom the prophecy is directed. This figure represents the leader of a hostile coalition against Israel, consistent with the eschatological adversary theme seen in Revelation 20:8 and Psalm 83:1-8.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 38, what does God say He will do to Gog and his army?
options: Put hooks into his jaws and bring him forth
Make him king of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Put hooks into his jaws and bring him forth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:4 states that God will put hooks into Gog’s jaws and bring him forth along with his army. This divine control over the enemy illustrates God's sovereignty over nations, paralleling Isaiah 10:5-7 and Daniel 2:21 where God directs the rise and fall of rulers.

questions.question: Which nations are specifically mentioned as allies of Gog in Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: Persia, Ethiopia, Libya, Gomer
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:5-6 lists Persia, Ethiopia, Libya, Gomer, and the house of Togarmah as allies of Gog. These represent a coalition of peoples opposing Israel, reflecting the motif of hostile nations in prophetic literature, similar to Joel 3:9-10 and Zechariah 14:2.

questions.question: What reason does Gog have for invading the land of Israel according to Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: To take spoil and prey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:11-12 states that Gog's intent is to take spoil and prey, attacking a land dwelling in safety without walls. This reveals the sinful motivation of greed and pride, echoing the biblical theme of human rebellion against God’s people as in Jeremiah 6:10 and Nahum 1:9.

questions.question: What is the significance of the land being described as 'brought back from the sword' and 'dwelling safely' in Ezekiel 38?
options: It indicates a restored Israel living in peace
It means Israel is conquered again
It refers to a foreign land
It describes a land without inhabitants
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a restored Israel living in peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:8 describes Israel as a land restored after judgment and gathered from many peoples, living safely. This points to a post-exilic, eschatological restoration, consistent with promises in Isaiah 11:11-12 and Jeremiah 30:10-11, and the New Testament hope in Romans 11:26-27.

questions.question: From which direction does Gog come against Israel according to Ezekiel 38?
questions.correctAnswer: From the north
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:15 states that Gog will come from the north parts. This directional detail is theologically significant, symbolizing the ultimate enemy’s approach as a divine test, paralleling Jeremiah 1:14 and Daniel 11:40 where northern powers threaten Israel.

questions.question: What divine purpose is served by God bringing Gog against Israel in the latter days?
options: That the nations may know God is sanctified
questions.correctAnswer: That the nations may know God is sanctified
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:16 explains that God brings Gog against Israel so that the heathen may know Him and that He will be sanctified in Gog before their eyes. This shows God's glory and holiness are revealed through judgment, consistent with Exodus 9:16 and Romans 9:17.

questions.question: How does God describe His reaction when Gog comes against Israel?
options: His fury will come up in His face
He will hide from the conflict
questions.correctAnswer: His fury will come up in His face
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:18 states that God's fury will come up in His face when Gog invades Israel. This anthropomorphic expression emphasizes God’s righteous anger against sin, resonant with passages like Nahum 1:2 and Romans 12:19 regarding God's just wrath.

questions.question: What cosmic disturbances accompany Gog's invasion of Israel according to Ezekiel 38?
options: Great shaking, mountains thrown down, walls falling
Sun darkened, stars falling, moon turned red
None; it is a peaceful invasion
questions.correctAnswer: Great shaking, mountains thrown down, walls falling
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:19-20 describes a great shaking in the land, with mountains and steep places falling, and walls collapsing at God's presence. This apocalyptic imagery parallels Joel 2:10, Haggai 2:6, and Revelation 6:12-14 illustrating divine intervention in history.

questions.question: What internal conflict does God say will occur among Gog’s forces?
options: Every man's sword shall be against his brother
questions.correctAnswer: Every man's sword shall be against his brother
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:21 reveals that God will cause division within Gog’s army so that every man’s sword is against his brother. This theme of internal strife as divine judgment is echoed in Judges 7:22 and Zechariah 14:13.

questions.question: What forms of divine judgment does God say He will bring upon Gog and his multitude?
options: Pestilence, blood, overflowing rain, great hailstones, fire, and brimstone
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence, blood, overflowing rain, great hailstones, fire, and brimstone
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:22 lists multiple judgments including pestilence, blood, rain, hailstones, fire, and brimstone. This comprehensive judgment underscores God’s power and justice, similar to the plagues in Exodus 9 and the judgment imagery in Revelation 16.

questions.question: What is the ultimate theological significance of God's judgment on Gog as stated in Ezekiel 38?
options: God will magnify and sanctify Himself and be known among many nations
God will create a new enemy
questions.correctAnswer: God will magnify and sanctify Himself and be known among many nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:23 states that through judgment on Gog, God will magnify and sanctify Himself and be known among many nations. This reveals God's glory is displayed through salvation and judgment, consistent with Isaiah 48:11 and John 12:28.

questions.question: What role does the prophecy against Gog play in the grand narrative of Scripture?
options: It depicts the ultimate defeat of evil before God's kingdom is fully established
It predicts immediate destruction of Israel
It serves as a warning to Egypt only
It describes a historical war in Ezekiel’s time
questions.correctAnswer: It depicts the ultimate defeat of evil before God's kingdom is fully established
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38 portrays an eschatological battle where God defeats the forces of evil, aligning with the biblical narrative of God's final victory over sin and Satan, as seen in Revelation 20:7-10 and Daniel 7:21-22.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 38 affirm the doctrine of God's sovereignty over nations and history?
options: God orchestrates Gog's invasion to fulfill His purposes
Nations act independently without God's knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: God orchestrates Gog's invasion to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes God bringing Gog out with hooks, directing the timing and outcome of the invasion (Ezekiel 38:4, 16). This affirms God's providential sovereignty over all earthly powers, consistent with Psalm 22:28 and Colossians 1:16-17.

questions.question: What does the mention of 'unwalled villages' in Ezekiel 38:11 signify about the spiritual state of Israel in this prophecy?
options: Israel is at rest and secure, trusting in God
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is at rest and secure, trusting in God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 38:11 describes Israel as dwelling safely without walls or gates, indicating divine protection and peace in the eschatological period. This reflects trust in God rather than human defenses, echoing Psalm 46:1-3 and Isaiah 32:17.
